data.question: For people undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy, what are the effects of intraperitoneal local anesthetic instillation?
data.gold_answer: For people undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy, low‐certainty evidence suggests that the pain intensity may be lower (by 0.7 to 1.0 points on a 1‐10 scale) both at 4 to 8 and 9 to 24 hours after surgery in people who received intraperitoneal instillation of local anesthetic, compared with those receiving no instillation. The instillation was most commonly performed at the end of the surgical procedure. Fewer people may experience nausea (174 vs 250 per 1000 people; based on 926 participants; all results on average) and vomiting (93 vs 140 per 1000 people; based on 1217 participants) with intraperitoneal local anesthetic instillation than with no local anesthetic. Moderate‐certainty evidence shows that the mean hospital stay was probably 0.1 days shorter after intraperitoneal local anesthetic instillation, but the clinical significance of such a small difference remains unclear. The effects of intraperitoneal local anesthetic instillation were very uncertain for the outcomes of mortality, same‐day discharge from the hospital, serious adverse events, and non‐significant adverse events.
data.gold_answer_terms:
INTRAPERITONEAL (intraperitoneal): into the abdominal cavity
LOCALIZED (localized): restricted to one area, limited to one area
ANESTHETIC (anesthetic): a drug or agent used to decrease the feeling of pain, or eliminate the feeling of pain by putting you to sleep
CLINICAL (clinical): pertaining to medical care
MORTALITY (mortality): death
data.llm_answer:
Intraperitoneal local anesthetic instillation in laparoscopic cholecystectomy provides several benefits, including:
1. Reduced postoperative pain: Instilling local anesthetic into the peritoneal cavity can help to reduce the pain associated with the surgery, resulting in less discomfort and improved pain management.
2. Improved respiratory function: By reducing pain and discomfort, patients are able to breathe more easily and deeply, which can help to improve respiratory function and reduce the risk of respiratory complications.
3. Shorter hospital stay: With reduced pain and discomfort, patients are often able to recover more quickly and may be able to leave the hospital sooner.
4. Reduced nausea and vomiting: Local anesthetic instillation can help to reduce nausea and vomiting, which are common side effects of laparoscopic surgery.
5. Improved patient satisfaction: By reducing pain and discomfort, patients are generally more satisfied with their surgical experience and may be more likely to choose laparoscopic surgery in the future.
It is important to note that the use of intraperitoneal local anesthetic instillation is not suitable for all patients undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy, and the decision to use this technique should be made on a case-by-case basis with the guidance of a qualified medical professional.

data.question: In women with locally advanced cervical cancer, how does neoadjuvant chemotherapy plus radical hysterectomy compare with chemoradiotherapy or radiotherapy alone for improving outcomes?
data.gold_answer: There is no definitive RCT evidence showing that neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NACT) plus radical hysterectomy (RH) is better than chemoradiotherapy (CCRT) or radiotherapy alone in women with locally advanced cervical cancer. Moderate‐certainty evidence shows likely similar survival rates with NACT plus RH compared with CCRT alone, and low‐certainty evidence suggests worse disease‐free survival with NACT + RH than with CCRT at a median follow‐up of 59 to 98 months. Evidence for toxicity, treatment‐related morbidity, and serious adverse events was of very low certainty, and no information on quality of life was reported. Moderate‐certainty evidence shows that, at a median follow‐up of 39 to 60 months, women who received NACT + RH probably had a lower risk of death than those who received radiotherapy alone. However, a non‐negligible proportion of the participants who received NACT + RH were given radiotherapy as well. Results for disease‐ or progression‐free survival may be better with NACT + RH, but are also compatible with little to no difference. Findings from single RCTs suggest similar grade 3 acute toxicity and severe late toxicity and severe adverse events between groups (low‐certainty evidence). No quality of life data were reported.
data.gold_answer_terms:
RCT (rct): A study which tests the effectiveness and safety of treatments or procedures as fairly and objectively as possible. By randomly assigning patients to different treatments for the same problem, the results can be assessed equally with the aim of discovering the best possible procedure for the condition.
CHEMOTHERAPY (chemotherapy): treatment of disease, usually cancer, by chemical agents
HYSTERECTOMY (hysterectomy): surgical removal of the uterus, ovaries (female sex glands), or both uterus and ovaries
LOCALIZED (localized): restricted to one area, limited to one area
CANCER (cancer): A disease of the cells.
TOXICITY (toxicity): side effects or undesirable effects of a drug or treatment
MORBIDITY (morbidity): undesired result or complication
RISK (risk): The chance that an activity or hazard will give rise to harm. Risk is generally given in terms of numerical odds (1 in 10) or percentages (10%).
ACUTE (acute): new, recent, sudden, urgent

data.question: For women with heavy menstrual bleeding, what are the effects of medical treatments?
data.gold_answer: Reviewers conducted an overview of Cochrane Reviews and network meta‐analysis to answer this question. Moderate‐certainty evidence shows that antifibrinolytics probably reduce menstrual blood loss (MBL) (by 80 mL/cycle, all results on average). Low‐certainty evidence suggests that levonorgestrel intrauterine device (LNG‐IUS) may result in a large reduction of MBL (by 106 mL/cycle), and long‐cycle progestogen may reduce MBL (by 77 mL/cycle). The effect of the remaining interventions on MBL is uncertain. The effect of any intervention as a first‐line treatment on women's perception of improvement is very uncertain. Regarding adverse events, the best treatment was placebo, followed by antifibrinolytics, non‐steroidal anti‐inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and LNG‐IUS. The worst treatments were luteal progestogens, combined oral contraceptive, and long‐cycle progestogens.
data.gold_answer_terms:
PROGESTOGEN (progestogen): A synthetic hormone, similar to progesterone. It thickens the mucus around the cervix, making it difficult for sperm to get into the womb or for a fertilised egg to implant in the womb.
PLACEBO (placebo): an inactive substance; a pill/liquid that contains no medicine
CONTRACEPTION (contraception): Contraception, or birth control, is what you and your partner can use to help prevent an unwanted pregnancy or to space out your pregnancies. There are many different forms of contraception  including condoms, hormonal pills and implants, hormonal and non-hormonal coils and permanent methods such as female sterilization or vasectomy. You can get more information about contraception from your GP or a family planning clinic.
data.llm_answer:
Medical treatments for heavy menstrual bleeding in women can have several effects, including:
1. Reduced bleeding: Hormonal medications, such as oral contraceptives, progestins, and gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists, can help reduce menstrual bleeding.
2. Regulated cycles: Hormonal treatments can also help regulate menstrual cycles, making them more predictable and manageable.
3. Reduced anemia: Treatments can help reduce the risk of anemia, a common complication of heavy menstrual bleeding, by increasing red blood cell production.
4. Improved quality of life: Effective treatment can improve a woman's overall quality of life, reducing discomfort, pain, and inconvenience associated with heavy menstrual bleeding.
5. Increased fertility: In some cases, medical treatments can improve fertility in women with heavy menstrual bleeding who may have been experiencing difficulty conceiving due to ovulation irregularities.
6. Potential side effects: Some medical treatments may have potential side effects, such as weight gain, mood changes, or changes in sexual function, which should be discussed with a healthcare provider.
7. Surgical intervention: In some cases, surgical intervention may be necessary, such as endometrial ablation or hysterectomy, which can be effective in reducing or eliminating menstrual bleeding.
It's important to note that the most appropriate treatment will depend on the underlying cause of the heavy menstrual bleeding, the severity of the condition, and the individual woman's overall health and medical history. A healthcare provider can help determine the best course of treatment for each woman.

data.question: What is the impact of nutritional standards on the consumption/sales of sugar‐sweetened beverages in schools?
data.gold_answer: Reviewers identified four nutritional standard interventions aimed at decreasing consumption/sales of sugar‐sweetened beverages in schools: reducing availability of these beverages; improving access to drinking water; giving small prizes (such as bracelets, pens, fancy pencils, notebooks, or toys) for selecting healthier beverages; and improving placement of healthier beverages in cafeterias. Moderate‐certainty evidence shows that giving small prizes probably reduces the number of meals per week for which children select unhealthy beverages. Low‐certainty evidence suggests that reduced availability of sugar‐sweetened beverages in schools may reduce consumption but improved placement of healthier beverages in cafeterias may not. The certainty of evidence for improving access to drinking water was rated as very low.
data.llm_answer: Nutritional standards in schools have had a significant impact on the consumption and sales of sugar-sweetened beverages. Studies have shown that schools that implement nutritional standards, such as the USDA's Smart Snacks in Schools program, have seen a reduction in the sales of sugar-sweetened beverages and an increase in the sales of water and other low-calorie drinks. Additionally, research has found that students who attend schools with stricter nutritional standards tend to have lower consumption of added sugars and higher consumption of fruits and vegetables. Overall, implementing nutritional standards in schools can be an effective strategy for promoting healthier beverage choices and reducing childhood obesity.

data.question: How does antibiotic prophylaxis compare with placebo for women undergoing elective hysterectomy?
data.gold_answer: In November 2016, reviewers identified 23 RCTs published between 1973 and 2002 that evaluated the impact of antibiotic prophylaxis for women undergoing elective vaginal or abdominal hysterectomy. Low‐certainty evidence suggested that antibiotic prophylaxis probably reduced the number of women contracting any postoperative infection (by 433 and 241 per 1000 women; all results average reductions for vaginal and abdominal hysterectomy, respectively). Moderate‐certainty evidence showed that antibiotic prophylaxis probably reduced specific types of infection (urinary tract by 42 and 63 per 1000 women, pelvic by 43 and 18 per 1000 women, and abdominal by 25 per 1000 women undergoing abdominal hysterectomy), incidence of postoperative fever (by 80 and 79 per 1000 women), the need for therapeutic antibiotics (by 55 and 69 per 1000 women), and duration of hospital stay (by approx. 1.4 days and 0.6 days). Evidence for adverse effects was available only for women undergoing abdominal hysterectomy and was rated by reviewers as very low certainty. Reviewers highlight that given the dates that RCTs were conducted, they may not reflect current practice in perioperative and postoperative care and/or may not show locoregional antimicrobial resistance patterns.

data.question: Does palivizumab help prevent severe respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection in infants?
data.gold_answer: For infants (mostly at high risk of RSV owing to prematurity or comorbidities) and compared with placebo or no intervention, high‐certainty evidence shows that use of palivizumab (15 mg/kg intramuscularly every month for up to five months) results in fewer infants hospitalized due to RSV infection (43 vs 97 per 1000 infants; all results on average) and fewer wheezing days (18 vs 45 per 1000 days). Moderate‐certainty evidence shows that palivizumab probably: leads to reduced hospitalization due to respiratory‐related illness (171 vs 220 per 1000 infants); has no clear impact on mortality; and does not increase adverse events. Fewer infants seem to have RSV with palivizumab than with placebo or no intervention (47 vs 140 per 1000 infants), although the certainty of evidence is low. Results for length of hospital or intensive care unit stay were imprecise.

data.question: What are the effects of convalescent plasma for people with moderate to severe COVID‐19?
data.gold_answer: Reviewers identified 21 RCTs (19,021 participants) evaluating the efficacy and safety of convalescent plasma (200 to 600 mL/kg or 4 to 13 mL/kg given as one or two infusions) versus no convalescent plasma for people with moderate to severe COVID‐19 receiving standard care. High‐certainty evidence shows that convalescent plasma had little to no impact on mortality within 28 days, clinical worsening (need for invasive mechanical ventilation or death), or clinical improvement (number of participants discharged). There were similar rates of serious adverse events and grade 3 to 4 events in both groups, based on moderate‐ to low‐certainty evidence. Low‐certainty evidence also suggests no impact of convalescent plasma on quality of life.

Convalescent plasma, also known as COVID-19 immune plasma, is a preparation of plasma (the liquid part of blood) that contains antibodies from people who have recovered from COVID-19. It is used to treat people with moderate to severe COVID-19, and has been shown to be effective in reducing the severity and duration of symptoms, as well as the risk of hospitalization and death.
Studies have shown that convalescent plasma can:
* Reduce the risk of severe illness and hospitalization by 50-70%
* Reduce the risk of intensive care unit (ICU) admission by 70-80%
* Reduce the risk of death by 50-70%
* Shorten the duration of symptoms by 2-4 days
* Reduce the amount of viral replication in the body
It is important to note that convalescent plasma is not a cure for COVID-19, and it is not a substitute for other treatments, such as antiviral medications or ventilation support. It is also not recommended for people with mild COVID-19, as the benefits are unlikely to outweigh the risks.
It is important to consult a healthcare professional for proper evaluation and treatment. They will be able to assess the severity of the illness and determine if convalescent plasma is appropriate for the individual case.

data.question: For adults with bronchiectasis, how does a 14‐day intermittent prophylactic antibiotic regimen compare with a 28‐day intermittent prophylactic antibiotic regimen?
data.gold_answer: In adults with non‐cystic fibrosis bronchiectasis, a 14‐day intermittent prophylactic regimen with fluoroquinolone compared with a 28‐day intermittent prophylactic regimen with fluoroquinolone did not result in a statistically significant difference in frequency of exacerbations (moderate‐certainty evidence), serious adverse events (moderate‐certainty evidence), development of antibiotic resistance (moderate‐certainty evidence), lung function (level of certainty not assessed), or health‐related quality of life (high‐certainty evidence). All outcomes were assessed at 48 weeks' follow‐up. For a comparison of intermittent prophylactic antibiotic treatment regimens with placebo for adults with bronchiectasis, see CCA 4012 .

data.question: What are the benefits and harms of indomethacin for treating symptomatic patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in infants?
data.gold_answer: High‐certainty evidence shows that compared with infants who received placebo, fewer infants who received indomethacin (214 vs 719 per 1000 infants; all subsequent results given as average values) had failure of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) closure after one week of treatment. In six RCTs with 211 participants, the proportion of infants who required rescue medical treatment appeared to be lower among those who received indomethacin versus those who received placebo (139 vs 396 per 1000 infants). However, due in part to underpowered analyses, there were no clear differences between groups in all other outcomes assessed, including bronchopulmonary dysplasia (measured either at 28 days of life or at 36 weeks' gestation; low‐certainty evidence), all‐cause mortality before discharge (moderate‐certainty evidence), and proportion of infants requiring surgical PDA ligation (moderate‐certainty evidence). There were also no differences between groups in necrotizing enterocolitis (≥ Bell stage 2) (low‐certainty evidence) and mucocutaneous or gastrointestinal bleeding (low‐certainty evidence). The reviewers found no RCTs assessing oliguria.

data.llm_answer:
Indomethacin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that has been used to treat symptomatic patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in infants. The benefits of using indomethacin for this purpose include:
* Effective closure of the PDA: Indomethacin has been shown to effectively close the ductus arteriosus in up to 80% of infants with symptomatic PDA.
* Reduced need for surgery: Indomethacin can help avoid surgical ligation of the PDA, which can be associated with risks and complications.
* Improved respiratory status: Indomethacin can help improve respiratory status in infants with PDA, which can lead to better oxygenation and reduced risk of respiratory failure.
However, there are also potential harms associated with the use of indomethacin for this condition, including:
* Gastrointestinal side effects: Indomethacin can cause gastrointestinal side effects such as diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
* Renal impairment: Indomethacin can reduce renal blood flow and increase the risk of renal impairment, particularly in premature infants.
* Increased risk of bleeding: Indomethacin can increase the risk of bleeding, particularly in infants with pre-existing bleeding disorders or those taking other medications that can increase the risk of bleeding.
* Uncertain long-term effects: The long-term effects of indomethacin use in infants are not well understood, and there is concern about potential adverse effects on the developing brain and other organs.
Overall, the benefits and harms of indomethacin for treating symptomatic PDA in infants must be carefully weighed on a case-by-case basis, and the decision to use the drug should be made by a qualified healthcare professional.

data.question: What are the benefits and harms of indomethacin for treating symptomatic patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in infants?
data.gold_answer: High‐certainty evidence shows that compared with infants who received placebo, fewer infants who received indomethacin (214 vs 719 per 1000 infants; all subsequent results given as average values) had failure of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) closure after one week of treatment. In six RCTs with 211 participants, the proportion of infants who required rescue medical treatment appeared to be lower among those who received indomethacin versus those who received placebo (139 vs 396 per 1000 infants). However, due in part to underpowered analyses, there were no clear differences between groups in all other outcomes assessed, including bronchopulmonary dysplasia (measured either at 28 days of life or at 36 weeks' gestation; low‐certainty evidence), all‐cause mortality before discharge (moderate‐certainty evidence), and proportion of infants requiring surgical PDA ligation (moderate‐certainty evidence). There were also no differences between groups in necrotizing enterocolitis (≥ Bell stage 2) (low‐certainty evidence) and mucocutaneous or gastrointestinal bleeding (low‐certainty evidence). The reviewers found no RCTs assessing oliguria.

data.question: For women with heavy menstrual bleeding, how does endometrial resection/ablation compare with minimally invasive hysterectomy in terms of re‐surgery, satisfaction with treatment, and adverse events?
data.gold_answer: For women with heavy menstrual bleeding, moderate‐certainty evidence shows that endometrial resection/ablation compared with minimally invasive hysterectomy probably results in more women requiring further surgery within one year (on average, 50 vs 6 per 1000 women) and in fewer women feeling satisfied at one year (on average, 871 vs 971 per 1000 women). Serious adverse events included re‐admission, cardiorespiratory events, and thromboembolic events; the pooled estimate was imprecise. The effect of endometrial resection/ablation compared with minimally invasive hysterectomy on intraoperative and immediate postoperative adverse events is uncertain.

data.question: What effect do adjunctive corticosteroids have on mortality and disability in people with tuberculous meningitis?
data.gold_answer: High‐quality evidence shows that children and adults with a clinical diagnosis of tuberculosis (TB) meningitis receiving an anti‐TB regimen are less likely to die within 24 months when an adjunctive corticosteroid is administered (312 versus 413 per 1000 people died with an adjunctive corticosteroid compared with no corticosteroid, respectively). Moderate‐quality evidence showed that this benefit was not sustained in the longer‐term (5 years). Low‐quality evidence suggests there was no benefit of an adjunctive corticosteroid in terms of reducing rates of disabling neurological deficit, ether within 24 months or at 5 years. There was no apparent impact of adjunctive corticosteroids on the incidences of hepatitis, hyperglycemia/glycosuria, gastrointestinal bleeding, or invasive bacterial infection but event rates were very low meaning conclusions cannot be drawn.
data.gold_answer_terms:
CLINICAL (clinical): pertaining to medical care
DIAGNOSIS (diagnosis): The way a medical professional recognises a condition or disease.
MENINGITIS (meningitis): Inflammation in the brain caused by a virus or bacteria.
REGIMEN (regimen): pattern of giving treatment
CORTICOSTEROIDS (corticosteroids): A group of hormones which may be used to suppress the body’s immune response or to reduce inflammation. Also used during pregnancy in women who are thought may have their baby prematurely. They reduce the chance of the baby having problems from being born prematurely. See also steroids.
TERM (term): Between 37 and 42 weeks of pregnancy.
NEUROLOGICAL (neurological): pertaining to the nervous system
GASTROINTESTINAL (gastrointestinal): Relating to the stomach and intestine.
INVASIVE (invasive): A medical procedure when a cut is made to the body or an instrument is inserted.

The use of corticosteroids has been associated with a significant reduction in mortality rates, from approximately 30-40% in untreated patients to around 10-20% in patients receiving corticosteroids. Additionally, corticosteroids have been shown to reduce the risk of long-term disability, such as hearing loss and cognitive impairment. However, the optimal dosage and duration of corticosteroid therapy for tuberculous meningitis are still uncertain and require further research.

data.question: Can probiotics administered to pregnant women help prevent morbidity and mortality in preterm infants?
data.gold_answer: Reviewers found no conclusive RCT evidence suggesting that administration of probiotics to pregnant women was superior or inferior to placebo in reducing morbidity or mortality in preterm infants. Low‐certainty evidence suggests that in pregnant women who received probiotics, the risk of preterm birth (< 37 weeks) and miscarriage/stillbirth was no more or less likely compared with those who did not receive probiotics. Only one RCT (159 infants) reported no incidences of early neonatal sepsis (≤ 3 days) in either trial arm. For most outcomes, event rates were very low or there were no events in both arms. There is a lack of data on neonatal short‐term (early or late sepsis, necrotizing enterocolitis, neonatal death, hospital stay) and long‐term (major neurodevelopmental disability) potential benefits or harms following probiotic administration. None of the trials included women with a previous history of preterm birth, multiple pregnancy, or uterine anomaly. Reviewers did not assess serious adverse maternal or neonatal adverse events following use of probiotics.
